http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: A reference to Christ's death upon Mount Calvary, as reported in Matthew 27.33: "And when they were come unto a place called Golgotha, that is to say, a place of a skull." According to John 29.34, a Roman soldier pierced Christ's side as he hanged from the cross. Shakespeare's Sergeant tells King Duncan that the army he has just encountered is as violent and remorseless as the soldiers who put Christ to death.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: Banquo, unconvinced that the Witches can see the future, makes reference to Ecclesiastes 11.6: "In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening withhold not thine hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good." Foretelling the future of men is, in this metaphor, like looking at a group of seeds and predicting which will take hold and sprout, and which won’t grow.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Deconstructing Macbeth: The Hyperontological View by Fawkner, Harald William

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: Here it is not only that the consequences of murder have not yet been fully grasped; murder is not fantastical merely because it is unreal and unfamiliar as a fully developed notion. The unit fantastical instead indicates that murder at this point of refuses to be, precisely, a fully developed notion. Thought has not formed the idea murder and conversely murder is not yet part of thought but part of what is fantastical.  Murder from this viewpoint is weird (fantastical), and the important word sequence “thought, whose murder” indicates that thought itself is drawn into dangers, risks and unrealities of murder, that thought and murder are coimplicative - but in a way that cannot yet (and perhaps never) be understood.

He seems to mean that the image of murder in his mind, although still only  a fantasy and not a reality, is nonetheless so powerful that is whole being is in a state of turmoil.

Shakespeare Online. 20 Aug. 2000. by Mabillard, A. in Macbeth Glossary.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value:
The metaphor of growth permeates the Bible, particularly the Old Testament. Notice Jeremiah 11.16: "For the Lord called thy name, a green olive tree, fair, and of goodly fruit; with the noise of a great tumult he hath kindled fire upon it, and the branches of it are broken."; Jeremiah 12.2: "Thou hast planted them, yea, they have taken root: they grow, yea, they bring forth fruit: thou art near in their mouth, and far from their reins."; and Psalms 92.12,13: "The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree: he shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon/Those that be planted in the house of the Lord shall flourish in the courts of our God".
In the New Testament, the metaphor appears in Corinthians 3.6,7: "I have planted, Apollos watered; but God gave the increase/So then neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase". Shakespeare is careful to illustrate Duncan's status as divinely appointed king throughout the play. Duncan's goodness is necessary to enhance Macbeth's feelings of guilt and remorse.

Shakespeare Online. 10 Aug. 2010. Macbeth. Ed. Thomas Marc Parrott.

We have to believe from Lady Macbeth's description that Macbeth is capable of great compassion and affection.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: he metaphors in which Lady MAcbeth frames the stopping up of remorse,that is,  suggests that she imagines an attack on the reproductive passages of her own body, on what makes her specifically female. And as she invites the spirits to her breasts, she reiterates the centrality of the attack specifically on maternal function: needing to undo the “milk of human kindness” in Macbeth, she imagines an attack on her own literal milk, its transformation into gall. This imagery locates the horror of the scene in lady Macbeth unnatural abrogation of her maternal function.

He states specifically “to prick the sides of my intent” and this is really important. this “intent” is a three-dimensional body in motion rather than an idea.  He's gone from the imagery of babes and cherubeans to beasts. Indeed, it is the beast within him that drives him 4 him forward.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: Those on the scene have rushed out into the chill morning air before being fully dressed. Therefore, they suffer in exposure(an “unsheltered or undefended condition”) due to their naked (unclothed, uncovered) Frailties (i.e. mortal physical bodies). Duncan’s murder also emphasises that (a) naked (“exposed and laid open to shame, reproach and contempt”) Frailties (moral weaknesses and liabilities to sin) suffer in exposure (“the unmasking or ‘showing up’ of an error, fraud, or evil”) and (b) when naked (“such as want the protection of God, which is our best covering”) mankind will suffer from frailty (“Mortalitie” ,”subjection unto death”).

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: This quote explains how a smile can be very deceiving. Even though you may think someone is your friend, they may well in fact be your enemy. This quote directly relates to Duncan and Macbeth. In the play, Macbeth invited Duncan to his house for a party, so Duncan assumed they were friends. But the invitation was actually a plain to murder Duncan. So this quote explains how you never know who your friend is and who your enemy is.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: Macduff offers here a striking image of universal suffering. The howl of orphans and widow echoes to heaven: heaven takes there cries as a blow to its own face, a sacrilege redoubling both the cause and the clamour of woe. Everything here is scoring and rebounding, an aural entrapment representing the claustrophobia of living beneath tyranny. But […] Shakespeare sets up a savage irony. Macduff has abandoned his wife and children to their fate; Lady Macduff explicitly blames him for this.

It has, after all, in biblical terms, had to receive the blood he (Macbeth) has shed. But also, in biblical terms, this tyrant bloody-sceptered will have to give his own blood to cleanse the land he has defiled.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Shakspeare's Genius Justified by Jackson, Z.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value: Avarice and lust are both sins; both turbulent passions; and, inherent in most men: figuratively, both are sips from the great tree of evil; and, so ingrafted in man, that, instead of of curbing their growth,passion, the cultivator, is suffered to suit the soil to the slips; which taking root, and branching out, overspread the natural inheritance of reason. But those pernicious roots, though equally strong, are not of equal durability; the one exists but for the summer of life; and, on its decay, the other strengthens, and even poisons that vital moisture which man should sweeten in the winter of his age. […] The sin of avarice takes deeper troot in man, according as he advances in the frosted winter of his age: whereas, the sin of lust lasts only during the summer of life.

He feels compelled to treat her and is saddened when he hears from the doctor that one cannot mend the emotionally ill. This leads Macbeth into a rant that almost accuses the doctor of not being a doctor at all because he's not able to cure someone emotionally sick. Macbeth is needing the doctor to be able to do something, use some drug that can help her in any way.

http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#annotatedT.@value:
Fear is a common feeling in life, sometimes we don’t want it, and sometimes we need it in order to achieve a potential goal. The quote in Act 5, Scene 5 of Macbeth “I have almost forgot the taste of fears” highlights Macbeths juxtaposing feelings from the beginning of the play. The quote is a metaphor and portrays a ‘stone’ like Macbeth who forgets the feelings of emotions, as it has been so long since Macbeth has been scared. Macbeth has not been scared for a while as he has been hurting others and no-one is brave enough to stop him.
Macbeth has changed throughout the play from an emotional man who would double guess his decisions to a person who will do anything for a certain title. Macbeth ‘forgets the taste of fear’ as he has been in a drought where his only thoughts are about power and not about his emotions or feelings. Macbeth only feeds on power and nothing else allows him to survive.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: It is used to specify the textual content of a particular FRBR expression.
This property is used to associate a frbr:Endeavour to a term in a particular classification system.
A document that this thing is the primary topic of.

The STORM (STOrytelling and Metaphors) ontology examines metaphors and their connections to storytelling theories by influential scholars. More specifically, the ontology focuses on metaphors found in Shakespearean works and the ways in which they reflect storytelling aspects. With this project we attempt to demonstrate that metaphors do not only throw light on the conscious or subconscious narrative methods employed by the author, but that they may also provide insight into the main ideas of a story. Ultimately, we argue that the topic of a story may be extracted by the metaphors found in the work.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: The multiplying villainies of nature do swarm upon him

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Nature here is seen as spawning unnumbered evils, and notable among them is the first of the evils defined in the play, rebellion, though this evil is later seen to be contrary to the better sort of Nature.

The merciless Macdonald
Worthy to be a rebel, for to that
The multiplying villainies of nature
Do swarm upon him - from the Western Isles
Of kerns and galloglasses is supplied,
And Fortune on his damned quarrel smiling, Showed like a rebel's whore.
They wounded many enemies; emphasis on the extent of the damage.

A reference to Christ's death upon Mount Calvary, as reported in Matthew 27.33: "And when they were come unto a place called Golgotha, that is to say, a place of a skull." According to John 29.34, a Roman soldier pierced Christ's side as he hanged from the cross. Shakespeare's Sergeant tells King Duncan that the army he has just encountered is as violent and remorseless as the soldiers who put Christ to death.
Linguistic expenditure causes us to feel that the power of human articulation is something structurally close to cutting/wounding/nihilation.

Except they meant to bathe in reeking wounds
Or memorise another Golgotha, 40
I cannot tell.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: If you can look into the seeds of time and say which grain will grow

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Time is represented as different seeds/paths that may or may not grow/occur, as something growing/unfolding or not

Banquo, unconvinced that the Witches can see the future, makes reference to Ecclesiastes 11.6: "In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening withhold not thine hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good." Foretelling the future of men is, in this metaphor, like looking at a group of seeds and predicting which will take hold and sprout, and which won’t grow.

If you can look into the seeds of time
And say which grain will grow and which will not,
Speak then to me, who neither beg nor fear
Your favours nor your hate.

Who was the thane, lives yet,
But under heavy judgement bears that life
Which he deserves to lose.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: My thought, whose murder yet is but fantastical

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: The thought is an independent, living entity that exists outside him, he can’t help having this thought even if he doesn’t like it

Here it is not only that the consequences of murder have not yet been fully grasped; murder is not fantastical merely because it is unreal and unfamiliar as a fully developed notion. The unit fantastical instead indicates that murder at this point of refuses to be, precisely, a fully developed notion. Thought has not formed the idea murder and conversely murder is not yet part of thought but part of what is fantastical.  Murder from this viewpoint is weird (fantastical), and the important word sequence “thought, whose murder” indicates that thought itself is drawn into dangers, risks and unrealities of murder, that thought and murder are coimplicative - but in a way that cannot yet (and perhaps never) be understood.

Introduces the idea of murder to the play, personifies the thought as “victim” of a murder, but the murder is as yet the product of a fantasy, and the real victim cannot even be referred to, let alone named.  [..] The complex expression suggests Macbeth mental agitation. He seems to mean that the image of murder in his mind, although still only  a fantasy and not a reality, is nonetheless so powerful that is whole being is in a state of turmoil.

My thought, whose murder yet is but fantastical,
Shakes so my single state of man that function
Is smothered in surmise, and nothing is, 140
But what is not.

The metaphor of growth permeates the Bible, particularly the Old Testament. Notice Jeremiah 11.16: "For the Lord called thy name, a green olive tree, fair, and of goodly fruit; with the noise of a great tumult he hath kindled fire upon it, and the branches of it are broken."; Jeremiah 12.2: "Thou hast planted them, yea, they have taken root: they grow, yea, they bring forth fruit: thou art near in their mouth, and far from their reins."; and Psalms 92.12,13: "The righteous shall flourish like the palm tree: he shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon/Those that be planted in the house of the Lord shall flourish in the courts of our God".
In the New Testament, the metaphor appears in Corinthians 3.6,7: "I have planted, Apollos watered; but God gave the increase/So then neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase". Shakespeare is careful to illustrate Duncan's status as divinely appointed king throughout the play. Duncan's goodness is necessary to enhance Macbeth's feelings of guilt and remorse.

I have begun to plant thee and will labour
To make thee full of growing
Losing oneself,  being consumed by desire

When I burned in desire to
question them further, they made themselves air, into which
they vanished.
Nature/character/personality is a container of traits

What thou art promised; yet do I fear thy nature,
It is too full o'th'milk of human kindness 15
To catch the nearest way.

He states specifically “to prick the sides of my intent” and this is really important. this “intent” is a three-dimensional body in motion rather than an idea.  He's gone from the imagery of babes and cherubeans to beasts. Indeed, it is the beast within him that drives him 4 him forward.

I have no spur
To prick the sides of my intent, but only
Vaulting ambition which o'erleaps itself
And falls on th'other
Frailty is hidden under layers when it comes to men

Those on the scene have rushed out into the chill morning air before being fully dressed. Therefore, they suffer in exposure(an “unsheltered or undefended condition”) due to their naked (unclothed, uncovered) Frailties (i.e. mortal physical bodies). Duncan’s murder also emphasises that (a) naked (“exposed and laid open to shame, reproach and contempt”) Frailties (moral weaknesses and liabilities to sin) suffer in exposure (“the unmasking or ‘showing up’ of an error, fraud, or evil”) and (b) when naked (“such as want the protection of God, which is our best covering”) mankind will suffer from frailty (“Mortalitie” ,”subjection unto death”).

And when we have our naked frailties hid
That suffer in exposure, let us meet 120
And question this most bloody piece of work
To know it further.
Smiling is a way to hide evil intentions, use of smile as a means/a hiding place/a tool

This quote explains how a smile can be very deceiving. Even though you may think someone is your friend, they may well in fact be your enemy. This quote directly relates to Duncan and Macbeth. In the play, Macbeth invited Duncan to his house for a party, so Duncan assumed they were friends. But the invitation was actually a plain to murder Duncan. So this quote explains how you never know who your friend is and who your enemy is.

Where we are,
There's daggers in men's smiles; the nea'er in blood,
The nearer bloody.

Being king is not just about the present and the title, but about legacy too (like the tree’s purpose isn’t to just be a tree but to bear fruit too); Macbeth’s reign will be of no consequence if the title doesn’t get passed down to his son

Upon my head they placed a fruitless crown
And put a barren sceptre in my gripe,
Thence to be wrenched with an unlineal hand,
No son of mine succeeding.

Being king is not just about the present and the title, but about legacy too (like the tree’s purpose isn’t to just be a tree but to bear fruit too); Macbeth’s reign will be of no consequence if the title doesn’t get passed down to his son

Due to Macbeth gripe (“violent seizure”) of the scepter (“Monarchy”, “Kingdom”), he suffers from “griping” (a pinching or gnawing at the hart”). The prophecy predict that Macbeth will be fruitless (“steril, barren, dry”) and therefore childless. […] Macbeth has gained nothing but a barren scepter. Macbeth will have no son succeeding, so the sovereignty is destined to be wretched from is own “line” by an “unilineal Hand”.

Upon my head they placed a fruitless crown
And put a barren sceptre in my gripe,
Thence to be wrenched with an unlineal hand,
No son of mine succeeding.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: whose loves I may not drop

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Support/love by allies/friends is only a tool for Macbeth to enhance his power and claim to his position

For certain friends that are both his and mine,
Whose loves I may not drop, but wail his fall
Who I myself struck down

Fleance’s actions/children will be detrimental for Macbeth’s plans, since Banquo’s descendants would be kings according to the prophecy; what Fleance will generate/give birth to, be it plans or kids, will ruin Macbeth, will bring his literal or metaphorical death

As far as Macbeth is concerned, Fleance has shown himself to be a worm by running off. He has "no teeth for the present," no guts to stand and fight. But, in due course, he'll develop the courage (the "venom") to come back and take revenge. This is just what Macbeth's afraid of.

There the grown serpent lies; the worm that's fled
Hath nature that in time will venom breed, 30
No teeth for th'present.
Macbeth’s courage is a fact, has an existence of its own as solid as a physical object

Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves
Shall never tremble.
Malcom is very sad, his chest feels heavy with sorrow; bosom is imagined as the container of sorrow (the heart has always been associated with feelings)

These lines are related to imagery found in Psalms 87.1: "By the rivers of Babel we sat, and there we wept, when we remembered Zion". For Malcolm, forced to flee his native Scotland and watch its destruction from afar, it is wholly appropriate to echo Psalms 87.1.

Let us seek out some desolate shade and there
Weep our sad bosoms empty.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: new sorrows strike heaven on the face

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: The sorrows are so severe that their impact feels like a physical blow; the actions of Macduff’s and Malcom’s opponents (Macbeth) are so unholy that their impact feels like a physical blow to heaven

Macduff offers here a striking image of universal suffering. The howl of orphans and widow echoes to heaven: heaven takes there cries as a blow to its own face, a sacrilege redoubling both the cause and the clamour of woe. Everything here is scoring and rebounding, an aural entrapment representing the claustrophobia of living beneath tyranny. But […] Shakespeare sets up a savage irony. Macduff has abandoned his wife and children to their fate; Lady Macduff explicitly blames him for this.

New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows 5
Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds
As if it felt with Scotland and yelled out
Like syllable of dolour.
Just referring to Macbeth causes him physical pain

This tyrant, whose sole name blisters our tongues,
Was once thought honest; you have loved him well -
He hath not touched you yet
Macbeth’s actions are wounding the country, his reign brings only harm (possibly a reference to how he got his title too)

Though it may not appear at first to be part of his torment, the land itself is now shown to be bleeding. It has, after all, in biblical terms, had to receive the blood he (Macbeth) has shed. But also, in biblical terms, this tyrant bloody-sceptered will have to give his own blood to cleanse the land he has defiled.
Avarice/sin is a separate, independent activity, a plant that keeps growing

Avarice and lust are both sins; both turbulent passions; and, inherent in most men: figuratively, both are sips from the great tree of evil; and, so ingrafted in man, that, instead of of curbing their growth,passion, the cultivator, is suffered to suit the soil to the slips; which taking root, and branching out, overspread the natural inheritance of reason. But those pernicious roots, though equally strong, are not of equal durability; the one exists but for the summer of life; and, on its decay, the other strengthens, and even poisons that vital moisture which man should sweeten in the winter of his age. […] The sin of avarice takes deeper troot in man, according as he advances in the frosted winter of his age: whereas, the sin of lust lasts only during the summer of life.

This avarice
Sticks deeper, grows with more pernicious root 85
Than summer-seeming lust, and it hath been
The sword of our slain kings;

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: tidings which I have heavily borne

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Bad news carried like a physical object/weight

When I came hither to transport the tidings
Which I have heavily borne, there ran a rumour
Of many worthy fellows that were out
The time has come for Macbeth’s downfall, like a tree ready to be harvested

This image is suggestive, awakening the notion of the ripe fruit which must be shaken from the tree.
Macbeth, and thus his stronghold, is "ripe for shaking". Compare Malcolm's words to Nahum 3.12: "All thy strongholds shall be like fig trees with the first ripe figs: if they be shaken, they shall even fall into the mouth of the eater."

Macbeth
Is ripe for shaking, and the powers above
Put on their instruments.
Revenge is consuming but also a driving force
The clearest meaning of this complex clause is that Malcolm and Macduff’s motives for revenge are powerful enough to make a dead, or near-dead, man answer the call to arms.
Revenges burn in them, for their dear causes
Memory is a field where all sorts of memories can grow

Canst thou not minister to a mind diseased,
Pluck from the memory a rooted sorrow,
Raze out the written troubles of the brain,
Sorrow is well rooted, has a strong presence in Lady Macbeth

This is describing how Macbeth is pleading for his wife's health. He feels compelled to treat her and is saddened when he hears from the doctor that one cannot mend the emotionally ill. This leads Macbeth into a rant that almost accuses the doctor of not being a doctor at all because he's not able to cure someone emotionally sick. Macbeth is needing the doctor to be able to do something, use some drug that can help her in any way.

Canst thou not minister to a mind diseased,
Pluck from the memory a rooted sorrow,
Raze out the written troubles of the brain,

Fear is like food, which either means that it can taste bad like unsavory food or that fear is necessary like food to a human; fear is part of being human, like nutrition so Macbeth is no longer human

Fear is a common feeling in life, sometimes we don’t want it, and sometimes we need it in order to achieve a potential goal. The quote in Act 5, Scene 5 of Macbeth “I have almost forgot the taste of fears” highlights Macbeths juxtaposing feelings from the beginning of the play. The quote is a metaphor and portrays a ‘stone’ like Macbeth who forgets the feelings of emotions, as it has been so long since Macbeth has been scared. Macbeth has not been scared for a while as he has been hurting others and no-one is brave enough to stop him.
Macbeth has changed throughout the play from an emotional man who would double guess his decisions to a person who will do anything for a certain title. Macbeth ‘forgets the taste of fear’ as he has been in a drought where his only thoughts are about power and not about his emotions or feelings. Macbeth only feeds on power and nothing else allows him to survive.
I have almost forgot the taste of fears;

Orlando’s complaint finds itself organized around the opposition of keeps and unkept. It opposes the correct norm of caring for one’s brother and of educating him to the sad reality of doing nothing of the sort : but he gains “nothing under him but growth”.
but I, his brother, gain nothing under him but growth;
BEING A GUEST IS INFERIOR POSITION
Their blood relation is a fact, as solid as an object, so Oliver is in the wrong for ignoring a bond so strong

but the same tradition takes not
away my blood, were there twenty brothers betwixt us.
BLOOD RELATION IS A SOLID OBJECT

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: hiding me from all gentleman-like qualities

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Oliver is keeping Orlando away from his birthright; being a gentleman doesn’t come naturally to nobles, but it is their right to learn how to be one, like a visitor in their house who they are expected to welcome (but Oliver is hiding Orlando from this visitor)

Because Orlando has not been raised as a gentleman of quality (“the gentry”), he does not think of himself to be gentleman-like (“like one of noble parentage). Nevertheless, Orlando embodies the ideal gentleman -like qualities of kindness and honor, while Oliver has inherited his father’s possessions but none of his qualities(“characteristics and accomplishments”).

you have
train'd me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all
gentleman-like qualities.
PERSONAL TRAIT IS A LIVING BEING

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: the spirit of my father grows strong in me

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Orlando stresses on the fact that he has inherited his father’s character and will not accept to be humiliated; he reminds his brother of their ties and of Oliver’s obligation towards their father

Orlando is disturbed by Oliver who does not live up to his role as primus inter pares. Accordingly, the growing ‘boy’(Orlando) tries to act against this. What Orlando is after, then, right from the beginning is an annulment of a vertical disorder.

The spirit of my father grows strong in
me, and I will no longer endure it;
PERSONAL TRAIT IS A LIVING ENTITY

but should I anatomize
him to thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must look pale and
wonder.
Oliver wants to manipulate Orlando into rushing to battle, motivation is a driving force

Nothing remains but that I kindle
the boy thither, which now I'll go about.
Rosalind wants to mock Touchstone, she thinks he’s as wise as an animal
Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom

My father's rough and envious disposition
Sticks me at heart.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: what passion hangs these weights upon my tongue

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Feeling is a living entity that obstructs Orlando from speaking. Speech is an independent entity that can’t be controlled by humans, Orlando can’t command his tongue to speak as if it were out of his control

Orlando speaks to himself after meeting Rosalind for the first time, shortly after his wrestling match. Orlando acknowledges that something, an emotion perhaps, has “mastered” him and reflects on how he became painfully tongue-tied when speaking to her. Orlando’s love for Rosalind takes hold fast, as does her love for him, and he quickly becomes the tortured lover.
What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue? I cannot speak to her, yet she urg'd conference

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Love is troublesome, a heart without love is as convenient as a field without weeds; when love appears it creates problems
I could shake them off my coat: these burs are in my heart.
LACK OF EMOTION IS A CLEAR FIELD
Attempt to overthrow your passions; wrestle picks up on try. The pun on a fall in wrestling and on falling in love symbolizes a reconciling of aggression and romance not present in Lodge.
Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.

Under the 1352 statute of Edward III […] the mere thought of deposing or assassinating a seated monarch was in itself treason. Rosaline protests her innocence by asserting that such a thought is as yet unborne.

As I do trust I am not- then, dear uncle,
Never so much as in a thought unborn
Did I offend your Highness.

Thou art a fool.
Room/bed as prison/security; Celia is objectified, her value lies in her royal blood
Untreasuresd, a Shakespearean coinage, implying both the preciousness of the princess and her chastity.

The ladies, her attendants of her chamber,
Saw her abed, and in the morning early
They found the bed untreasur'd of their mistress.

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Envenoms means kill by poison. In the true order of things a man’s virtues and graces should assist him in his life, but here a man’s virtues are a danger to him, exciting the envy of others. The true order of things is inverted.

Envenoms him that bears it!

How many actions most ridiculous
Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: He’s perpetually sad/nostalgic and melancholy is like food for him to remain in this state; art is necessary for him to cope in exile

Melancholy is, for Jacques, also a lifestyle choice. He plays up his role, and specifically chooses behaviours aimed at intensifying this state. He is introduced listening to a song. He disregards the warning that music might intensify his melancholy. [...] Jacques melancholy is a carefully cultivated addiction.

More, I prithee, more. I can suck melancholy
out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs.

It is my only suit,
Provided that you weed your better judgments
Of all opinion that grows rank in them
That I am wise.
CLEAR THINKING IS A CLEAN GARDEN
Wise people are under scrutiny (in contrast with the fools, who are free to say what they want since no one pays attention to them)

The wise man's folly is anatomiz'd
Even by the squand'ring glances of the fool.

http://purl.org/spar/c4o/hasContent.@value: cleanse the foul body of the infected world

https://github.com/stormOntology/stormOn.@value: Society is sick because of people lying and keeping up appearances;  if more people were like fools, speaking their mind freely, the world would be a better place

Jaques delights in being sad—a disparate role in a play that so delights in happiness. Jaques believes that his melancholy makes him the perfect candidate to be Duke Senior’s fool. Such a position, he claims, will “Give me leave / To speak my mind,” and the criticism that flows forth will “Cleanse the foul body of th’infected world”

To speak my mind, and I will through and through
Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world,
If they will patiently receive my medicine.

The syphilitic imagery of that, the shock it administers about the possible origins of Jacques attitudes and behaviour, and the fierce energy with which he and the duke debate the question of the satirist’s right to criticize his fellow sinners, take the role of Jaques in a direction altogether different from that of the “motley minded gentleman” he so admires.

For thou thyself hast been a libertine,
As sensual as the brutish sting itself;
And all th' embossed sores and headed evils
That thou with license of free foot hast caught
Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.
Orlando pretending to be savage is a disguise, so that he, otherwise gentle, can fit in/survive in a world of savages

I thought that all things had been savage here,
And therefore put I on the countenance
Of stern commandment.

http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#com.@value: Son of Northumberland
Compares metaphors with contrasting meanings across or within genres and works
States the shared qualities of the source and target domains.
States whether the direction of the metaphor is from concrete to abstract or from abstract to concrete
States whether trial functions as marking of the hero
Relates metaphors with similar meaning across or within genres and works

Brings together mirroring metaphors. According to Yorke's theory, the 5 acts that comprise a story mirror each other in terms of content in this fashion: the first act mirrors the fifth, the second mirrors the fourth, and the two halves of the midpoint mirror each other.
Indicates a pattern of metaphors and summarizes their content under a general metaphor
